metadata.title: Insight into the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction of cinnamaldehyde over MgAl oxides catalysts

Table 4 Conditions Selectivity (%) Conversion (%) COL HCOL 1-ONE CPE 10wt%, 70°C 93.3 0.8 5.9 0 16.1 10wt%, 80°C 92.8 0.5 6.7 0 37.3 10wt%, 90°C 89.1 0.7 10.2 0 46.1 5wt%, 80°C 86.6 1.0 12.4 0 68.4 12wt%, 80°C 96.5 0.7 2.8 0 17.2 15wt%, 80°C 89.6 0 0.9 9.5 6.7 Editor’s choice paper Insight into the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction of cinnamaldehyde over MgAl oxides catalysts Zihui Xiao Tianjin Key Laboratory of Advanced Functional Porous Materials, Institute for New Energy Materials & Low-Carbon Technologies, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin 300384, China Tianjin Key Laboratory of Advanced Functional Porous Materials Institute for New Energy Materials & Low-Carbon Technologies School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University of Technology Tianjin 300384 China Graphical abstract The synergistic effect of weak and moderate base sites was responsible for the MPV reduction of cinnamaldehyde. The Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) reduction of cinnamaldehyde with 2-propanol to cinnamyl alcohol over MgAl oxide catalysts originated from hydrotalcites was systematically studied. By investigating the influence of calcination temperature and Mg/Al molar ratio on alkaline density and catalytic performance, the relationship between alkaline density and catalytic performance had been established. It was well confirmed that there was an optimal W/M alkaline density ratio for cinnamaldehyde reduction, which lay in the synergetic effect of weak base sites and moderate base sites. In addition, the reaction parameters, reaction pathway, and stability of catalyst were also investigated. Interestingly, the formation of 5-methyl-3-phenylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (1-ONE) was observed for the first time by condensation of cinnamaldehyde and 2-propanol, which was promoted by increasing total alkaline density. And 1-cinnamyl 2-propyl ether (CPE) was detected just under high starting cinnamaldehyde concentration. In the recycling, the used MgAl oxide catalyst exhibited poor activity due to the strong adsorption of organic molecular on active sites, while its reactivity was recovered by calcining simply. Keywords MPV reduction Cinnamaldehyde MgAl oxide catalysts Hydrotalcite Alkaline density 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes is crucial in the manufacture of flavors, pharmaceuticals [1]. Besides, selective cinnamaldehyde hydrogenation is also an important model reaction for investigating the hydrogenation behaviors of CC and CO bonds, and the catalytic performances of the catalysts. Considering the hydrogenation of CC bond is much more thermodynamically favorable, much efforts have been cast toward improving the selectivity of the desired product of cinnamyl alcohol [2]. Supported metal catalysts are widely applied for the selective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde to cinnamyl alcohol [3–9]. Generally, for enhancing the selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol, several strategies have been developed, such as using bimetallic catalysts [4], modifying the surface via capping agents [5], controlling the sizes of metal NPs [6], introducing promoters [7], tuning the composition of support [8], using supercritical liquid moderate [9], and so on. However, the hydrogenation was performed under certain pressure with gaseous hydrogen, resulting in an increase in the equipment cost and experiments risk. As known, the MPV reaction is highly selective for reducing carbonyl compounds in the presence of other reducible sites [10], which provide a promising way for selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes under atmospheric pressure by hydrogen transfer using an alcohol as hydrogen donor. Originally, the MPV reaction was carried out in the homogenous phase with metal alkoxides. Subsequently, various metal oxides with either Lewis acidic and/or basic properties have also been found to be active in the MPV reaction. Nevertheless, the basic oxides were better than acidic ones in terms of stability and selectivity, since acidic catalysts frequently lead to secondary products that form by alcohol dehydration or condensation of the aldehyde [11]. As known, the alkalinity of Mg-Al mixture oxide obtained by calcining hydrotalcite-like compounds could be carefully adjusted by changing the preparation parameters. This facilitates their use in base-catalyzed reactions such as that of MPV reaction. In previous work, the Mg-Al mixture oxide has been exhibited excellent performance in the MPV reduction of unsaturated aldehydes [12–14]. It was found that the catalytic activity was found to be a function of surface alkalinity. However, it remains unclear that the relationship between the type of base sites and activity. For the Mg-Al mixture oxides, the alkaline properties involving the amount and strength of base sites, is depend on a wide variety of parameters such as the metal ion cations present, their ratio in the layered matrices, the presence of alkali dopes, the nature of interlayer anions, and thermal treatments. Thus, it is greatly important to investigate the variation of alkalinity with preparation parameters for establishing the relationship between alkalinity and activity. Aramendía et al. [12] and Kumbhar et al. [13] reported that highly selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol was observed over Mg-Al mixture oxides catalysts under mild conditions, while the influence of reaction parameters, the reaction pathway, and the stability of catalyst were not systematically investigated yet. In this study, the effect of the calcination temperature and Mg/Al molar ratios on the activity and the relation of the textural, structural, and chemical properties of MgAl oxides on the MPV reduction of cinnamaldehyde are investigated. The relationship between alkalinity and activity is also established. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation MgAl hydrotalcites were prepared by coprecipitation from aqueous solutions at 70°C. Solution A containing appropriated amounts of Na2CO3 and NaOH (OH−/CO3 2− =5 and CO3 2− + OH− =0.6M, 100mL) was slowly dropped under vigorous stirring to solution B containing nitrate precursors (Mg+Al=0.15M, 200mL). The formed precipitates were aged in their mother liquor for 4h at 70°C and then filtered, washed with boiling distilled water until Na+ was no longer detected in the filtrate, and dried at 100°C overnight. The formed hydrotalcites precursors were decomposed in air at a certain temperature for 2h in order to obtain the corresponding MgAl oxides catalysts. For instance, after calcined at 500°C, the obtained MgAl oxides catalyst with Mg/Al molar ratio of 3 was designated as Mg3Al1-500 catalyst. After reaction, the recycled catalysts without calcination were designated as Mg2Al1-600-R, Mg3Al1-600-R, and Mg4Al1-600-R catalyst, respectively. The Mg3Al1-600-RC catalyst was obtained by calcining of the Mg3Al1-600-R catalyst at 500°C for 2h. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-7000S diffractometer with a Cu Kα monochromatized radiation source (λ=1.5418Å), operated at 40KV and 30mA. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured by static N2 physisorption at 77K with a Quantachrome Instruments Autosorb-iQ-C automated gas sorption analyzer. Before the N2 physisorption measurement, all samples of approximately 0.1–0.2g were heated to 150°C under vacuum (10−3 Torr) for at least 3h to remove adsorbed impurities. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The total pore volume was derived from the adsorbed N2 volume at a relative pressure of approximately 0.99, and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the pore size distributions according to the desorption branch of the isotherms. Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) analyses of the catalysts were performed on a Micromeritic sautochem II 2910 automated catalyst characterization system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to measure the CO2 desorption and an on-line mass spectrometer (Omini-star, GSD-300) to detect any organic or inorganic species in the effluent stream during the CO2-TPD experiment. Usually, 0.1g of a sample was loaded in a quartz reactor and pretreated in He at 300°C for 1h. After the sample was cooled to 50°C in He stream, the sample was exposed to pure CO2 (20mLmin−1) for 1h until completely adsorbed saturation. The physisorbed CO2 was removed by passing He over the catalyst at 50°C for 1h. The CO2-TPD of the pre-adsorbed catalyst was performed under He flow at a temperature ramp of 10°C from 50 to 500°C, while monitoring the thermal conductive detector (TCD) signals. Particle morphologies were examined with scanning electronmicroscopy (SEM). Measurements were made using a JEOL JSM-5600LV SEM operated at 10KeV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was performed by using a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 TEM, operated at 200kV. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The MPV reduction of cinnamaldehyde was performed in a 50mL glass tube reactor with reflux condenser and magnetic stirrer. A reaction mixture of 3.6g (60mmol) 2-propanol, 0.4g (3mmol) cinnamaldehyde, and 0.3g catalyst was placed in the reactor. The mixture was refluxed with stirring at a temperature of 80°C. The products were analyzed with a 7890F gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. A FFAP GC column (30m×0.32mm×0.5μm) was used for separation. A known amount of n-butanol solution was used as internal standard for analysis. The various reaction products were also identified by GC/MS. 3 Results and discussion X-ray diffraction patterns of as-synthesized MgAl hydrotalcites, presented in Fig. 1 , reveal a pure hydrotalcite (HT) phase (JCPDS no. 41-1428). Diffraction patterns were consistent with the proposed hydrotalcite structure, consisting of layered double hydroxides with brucite-like layers and Mg6Al2(OH)16CO3·4H2O stoichiometric composition. After calcination, the peaks corresponding to MgAl oxides (LDO) were apparent in the Mg3Al1 catalysts. The diffraction intensity of these peaks was enhanced with elevating the calcination temperature, suggesting that an increase in the crystallinity was detected at high temperature. While the spinel MgAl2O4 was not observed even at high temperature of 800°C, which was likely due to the low content of Al. During calcination, the transformation of structure was described in detail. Originally, Al3+ occupied octahedral sites in hydrotalcite structure. After calcination, the Al3+ transferred from octahedral to tetrahedral sites and Mg2+ was isomorphously substituted in the mixed oxides. And Al3+ entered the MgO lattice and partly substituted for Mg2+ in the Mg-Al oxides [15]. Finally, Al3+ was well dispersed in the catalyst structure and formed an aluminium-doped MgO oxide. The BET surface areas, pore volume, and mean pore size for the calcined Mg3Al1 catalysts are listed in Table 1 . Obviously, the BET surface areas for the Mg3Al1 samples were declined gradually with increasing the calcination temperature. During calcination, the interlayer anion decomposition and radical splitting occurred, and the escape of small molecules led to the formation of microporous and mesoporous structures. Thus an increase in total volume, mesoporous volume, and mean pore size between 400 and 600°C was observed. However, the total volume and mesoporous volume were significantly decreased by further elevating temperature, since the ordered layers structure was partly destroyed. Because of that, the small pores could be blocked led to an increase in the mean pore size at high calcination temperature. Moreover, with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio, the surface area was declined. The XRD patterns of MgAl hydrotalcites with varied the Mg/Al molar ratios are also shown in Fig. 2 . These exhibited the diffraction peaks for the basal (003), (006), and (110) planes at 2θ=11.3°, 22.7°, and 60.6°, respectively, which were characteristic peaks of HT phase. Cell parameters c and a of the triple hexagonal unit cell, calculated assuming a 3R1 symmetry stacking, are presented in Table 2 . Cell parameter a (=2d110) is a function of cation–cation distance in hydrotalcite-like layer, while the value of parameter c (=3d003 =6d006) is the thickness of one hydrotalcite-like layer and one interlayer [16]. The change of interlayer distance (c) is related to the layer charge density. When larger Al3+ substitution degree, there is a stronger electrostatic attraction between positively charged sheets and interlayer anions. Therefore, the layers are packed closer together in hydrotalcites. The average crystallite sizes of hydrotalcites in the c- and a-directions were determined by the Scherrer equation using the XRD peaks for (003) and (110) planes, respectively. It was noteworthy that the crystallite sizes of MgAl hydrotalcites in the c- and a-directions decreased with increasing the Mg/Al molar ratio. This means that the hydrotalcites with high Mg/Al molar ratio retained a smaller number of stacked layers (from exfoliation of layers) and a shorter layer length (from vertical breaking of layers) [17]. As expected, the diffraction peaks corresponding to LDO phase was observed after heat post-treatment. While there were unobvious difference in crystalline phases apart from the diffraction intensity. Correspondingly, the peaks of recycled catalysts were not changed comparing to that of the catalyst before reaction, indicated that the structure of MgAl catalysts exhibited excellent stability. The surface alkalinity of the MgAl oxides catalysts was measured by CO2-TPD (Fig. 3 ). And the alkaline species could be assigned according to the temperature at CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to base sites exhibiting weak (W), moderate (M) and high strength (H), respectively. Among these, the two peaks centered at low temperature were assigned to the desorption peaks of CO2 linked with the weak base sites. The number of basic sites was estimated by deconvolution and integration of these peaks. Meanwhile, the alkaline density (base sites amount per unit surface area of catalysts) was also calculated as listed in Table 3 . It was supposed that the weak base sites were the surface OH− groups. The moderate base sites were associated with the oxygen in both Mg2+-O2− and Al3+-O2− pairs. With increasing the calcination temperature, the alkaline density assigned to weak base sites was decreased, while that was increased for moderate base sites. The presence of moderate sites was favored in MgAl mixed oxides due to the higher electronegativity of Al3+compared with Mg2+, which decreased the electron density and thus the nucleophilicity of the neighboring oxygen anions. Consequently, higher density of moderate base sites was found in the higher Mg/Al molar ratio catalysts. The strong base sites were related to the coordinatively unsaturated O2− anions. Since Al3+ ion was more positive than Mg2+ ion, the introduction of Al3+ in the MgO lattice resulted in decrease of density of the coordinatively unsaturated O2− anions [18]. As a result, the strength and density of the strong base sites decreased with decreasing the Mg/Al molar ratio. The SEM images of the Mg3Al1-600 catalysts before and after reaction are shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that all of catalysts show plate-like sheet structure with irregular size and different thickness (t). Estimated from the SEM images, the thickness of recycled catalyst (Mg3Al1-600-R) was increased from t =10.2nm to t =14.6nm, which was likely attributed to the increase of interlayer spacing, since substrates and products could enter into interlayer. As expected, after calcination (Mg3Al1-600-RC), the sheet thickness recovered to that presented in catalyst before reaction. TEM was performed to obtain further information on the different morphologic features of the samples as shown in Fig. 5 . All of catalysts exhibited plate-like sheets that vertical to plane as observed in SEM images. According to FFT diffraction spot, the MgAl LDO oxides phases in the Mg3Al1-600 catalyst and Mg3Al1-600-RC catalyst were identified by lattice spacing, which was consisted with the observation in XRD results. While the lattice could not be distinguish in the Mg3Al1-600-R catalyst due to the coverage of organic molecular. Interestingly, a novel morphology was observed as shown in Fig. 5d and e, seemed like a sheet covered by a crystalline phase. The lattice spacing of d =2.7455Å was obtained, while the corresponding phase was not clear, which need to further investigate. The MPV reduction of cinnamaldehyde (CAL) with 2-propanol was performed over the MgAl oxides catalysts. During the reaction, 2-propanol was oxidized to acetone, and cinnamaldehyde was reduced selectively to cinnamyl alcohol (COL) as main product (Scheme 1 ). Meanwhile, over-hydrogenation of COL to hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCOL) was also detected. Due to an excess of 2-propanol, it could react with CAL forming 5-methyl-3-phenylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (1-ONE), and react with COL forming 1-cinnamyl 2-propyl ether (CPE) under high starting CAL concentration, which would be discussed in later. It was noteworthy that hydrocinnamaldehyde (HCAL) via CC hydrogenation was not detected in our work. For the formation of 1-ONE, it was likely that cinnamaldehyde reacted with 2-propanol by the aldol condensation firstly, and then the intramolecular cyclization occurred by releasing H2 due to the presence of double CC band, which was needed to further confirm. As known, the MPV reduction was performed over the base sites of the oxide catalysts via a cyclic six-membered transition state [19]. This suggested that the reactivity was highly dependent on the type and density of base sites. Therefore, the effect of calcination temperature on the cinnamaldehyde reduction was investigated as shown in Fig. 6 . Expectedly, the reactivity of the Mg3Al1 oxides catalysts was significantly changed with the calcination temperature. Specifically, the conversion of cinnamaldehyde was increased from 23.4% for the Mg3Al1-400 catalyst to 37.3% for the Mg3Al1-600 catalyst, before decreased gradually over the catalysts after calcined at higher calcination temperature. The selectivity towards COL was maintained above 89% for all of catalysts, while high selectivity of 1-ONE (10.5%) was obtained over the Mg3Al1-500 catalyst, which was related to the alkaline density. Similarly, the performance of MgAl oxide catalysts with different Mg/Al molar ratios for cinnamaldehyde reduction has also been compared as shown in Fig. 7 . The Mg3Al1-600 catalyst exhibited the highest cinnamaldehyde conversion, while the high selectivity of 1-ONE was obtained over the Mg4Al1-600 catalyst. In the MPV reduction, it is well known that the reducing alcohol adsorbs with the oxygen and hydrogen of the hydroxyl group to the Lewis basic metal ion and the oxo-ion site, respectively. In addition, the carbonyl group coordinates by hydrogen bonding to this surface hydroxyl group rather than to the metal [19]. Thus, the amount of weak and moderate base sites plays a very important role in the MPV reduction performance. For establishing the relationship between alkaline density of catalyst and catalytic activity, the ratio of weak alkaline density to moderate alkaline density as function of cinnamaldehyde conversion had been plot as shown in Fig. 8 . It was notable that the cinnamaldehyde conversion increased with increasing the W/M alkaline density ratio at the beginning, and subsequently decreased, suggesting that there was an optimal W/M alkaline density ratio for the best catalytic activity. The great performance was attributed to the synergetic effect of weak base sites and moderate base sites, where the weak base sites and moderate base sites were responsible for the adsorption of cinnamaldehyde and 2-propanol, respectively. In addition, high alkaline density was benefited to the occurrence of condensation reaction, resulting in the formation of 1-ONE. Fig. 9 shows content-time profile for cinnamaldehyde reduction over the Mg3Al1-600 catalyst, corresponding reaction results are also listed in Table 4 . Obviously, elevating reaction temperature was benefited to the increase of reactivity. The cinnamaldehyde conversion increased from 16.1% to 46.1%, and its reduction rate was also greatly improved. The selectivity towards COL was slightly declined at high reaction temperature. Meanwhile the formation of 1-ONE was promoted. The effect of cinnamaldehyde concentration on the performance of MPV reduction was examined. With increasing the cinnamaldehyde concentration, a decrease in cinnamaldehyde conversion was observed (in Table 4). The selectivity of 1-ONE exhibited the same tendency. It was noteworthy that CPE was formed just under high starting cinnamaldehyde concentration. Those might be related to the competitive adsorption and the difficulty of desorption. The underline reason is not clear, which need to further investigate. The recycling procedure of the Mg3Al1-600 catalyst was performed to examine the stability of that. In the recycling experiment, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with ethanol. Then the catalyst was dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h. In Fig. 10 , it could be seen that the Mg3Al1-600-R catalyst exhibited poor activity due to the coverage by organic substitutes, which was in accord with the observation in TEM images as shown in Fig. 5. Additionally, the color of catalyst changed from white to yellow after reaction (not shown), which could also prove those above mentioned. It was noteworthy that the high selectivity of 1-ONE was obtained over the Mg3Al1-600-R catalyst, although the conversion of cinnamaldehyde was quite low. This was likely caused by the residue of 1-ONE in the interlayer of catalyst, which could be leaching out by the replacement of 2-propanol during the reaction. After calcination, the reactivity was recovered, indicated that the MgAl oxides catalysts exhibited excellent structure stability as the XRD, SEM and TEM results. 4 Conclusions The MgAl oxides catalysts originated from hydrotalcites showed great performance for the MPV reduction of cinnamaldehyde. As expect, high selectivity to COL was observed, while 1-ONE was detected for the first time by condensation of cinnamaldehyde and 2-propanol. By adjusting the calcination temperature and Mg/Al molar ratio, the alkaline density of catalysts was significantly changed. And then the relationship between alkaline density and catalytic performance had been established. It was found that there was an optimal W/M alkaline density ratio for cinnamaldehyde reduction. The great performance was attributed to the synergetic effect of weak base sites and moderate base sites, where the weak base sites and moderate base sites were responsible for the adsorption of cinnamaldehyde and 2-propanol, respectively. Additionally, it is more susceptible to the formation of 1-ONE over the MgAl oxides catalysts with higher alkaline density. With increasing the cinnamaldehyde concentration, a decrease in cinnamaldehyde conversion was observed. It was noteworthy that CPE was formed just under high starting cinnamaldehyde concentration. At last, the MgAl oxides catalysts exhibited good structure stability, but the direct recycling performance was poor since the active sites were covered by organic substances. coredata.dc:description: The Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) reduction of cinnamaldehyde with 2-propanol to cinnamyl alcohol over MgAl oxide catalysts originated from hydrotalcites was systematically studied. By investigating the influence of calcination temperature and Mg/Al molar ratio on alkaline density and catalytic performance, the relationship between alkaline density and catalytic performance had been established. It was well confirmed that there was an optimal W/M alkaline density ratio for cinnamaldehyde reduction, which lay in the synergetic effect of weak base sites and moderate base sites. In addition, the reaction parameters, reaction pathway, and stability of catalyst were also investigated. Interestingly, the formation of 5-methyl-3-phenylcyclopent-2-en-1-one (1-ONE) was observed for the first time by condensation of cinnamaldehyde and 2-propanol, which was promoted by increasing total alkaline density. And 1-cinnamyl 2-propyl ether (CPE) was detected just under high starting cinnamaldehyde concentration. In the recycling, the used MgAl oxide catalyst exhibited poor activity due to the strong adsorption of organic molecular on active sites, while its reactivity was recovered by calcining simply.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley reduction of cinnamaldehyde over MgAl oxides catalysts
